text: I actually think the ideal language for most programmers is just some variant of Java :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: I actually think the ideal language for most programmers is just some variant of Java

text:
Could also be that these people are focussed on the first order problem they need to solve for their job/hobby/study, and are not in the position to zoom out and think broadly, or are not aware of the broad range of possibilities.

I mean, we all fancy ourselves imagineers, but none of us are actually entertaining ideas like “do what I mean not what I say, perfectly” because we know how damned impossible that’d be to build. We’re all focussed on what we think we can actually build. Safe to assume they are too.

text: The journey to enlightenment is a long one... if only syntax was a little better... syntax doesn't matter in the least... syntax matters, but not at all how I originally thought.

elements.text: The journey to enlightenment is a long one... if only syntax was a little better... syntax doesn't matter in the least... syntax matters, but not at all how I originally thought.

text:
> Could also be that these people are focussed on the first order problem they need to solve for their job/hobby/study

I might give you that if this subreddit were't filled with hobbyist programming language designers!

elements.text: Could also be that these people are focussed on the first order problem they need to solve for their job/hobby/study
I might give you that if this subreddit were't filled with hobbyist programming language designers!

text: If you ask people what kind of eating utensil they wish they had, they can't imagine anything but what they know; it takes a genius to invent the spork, the trong, and the splayd. If you ask people to imagine a color they haven't seen, they can't. Invention is not primarily driven by minor improvements. Small improvements are the realm of the engineer, which is a very conservative profession. I foolishly attended an engineering school, when i would have been happier in a science-oriented university. The training of engineers is primarily negative: they see what failed, and avoid it, using safe-for-deployment proven methods. Really quite opposite in their fundamental attitudes about change. The artist/inventor boldly goes where nobody imagines, and often suffers greatly because people reject things oftentimes when it is too far from their current experience. For example, I was one of a lucky few students who attended a talk by John Backus, the inventor of FORTRAN, about his new Functional language, and when he told the professors in attendance that you couldn't update a variable they were shocked and leaving the room all shook their heads and exclaimed he was a madman. Fast forward to now and everyone and their brother is talking about functional languages. As the old Panasonic slogan goes "slightly ahead of our time", it is far more lucrative to be slightly ahead than way ahead!

text: This is also where the dilemma stems from. Not all things that are new are also of value. Yet, both a thing that is of value, like your FORTRAN example, and a thing that is not of value might elicit the same reaction and feedback. Understanding on which side you are can be quite when receiving end of that feedback :slightly_smiling_face:.
